answers.a: A sharp, pungent, acrid odor often associated with household cleaners or urine; it’s noticeable even at very low levels.

answers.q: why does my pee smell like ammonia
answers.a: Commonly from dehydration concentrating urea (which can break down to ammonia); foods, vitamins, or a urinary tract infection can also cause it. Try drinking more water and see a clinician if it persists or comes with pain, burning, fever, or other symptoms.

In foods, E527 (ammonium hydroxide) is a pH regulator and processing aid used in items like cocoa, caramel color, and some baked goods, and it can be used to reduce surface bacteria on some meats under regulation. Outside food, it’s found in household cleaners and various industrial applications.

answers.q: why does my urine smell like ammonia
answers.a: Usually from concentrated urine due to dehydration, diet (e.g., asparagus, coffee), or supplements; infections can also produce this odor. Hydrate and consult a healthcare professional if it continues or is accompanied by burning, pain, or fever.

answers.q: why does my vagina smell like ammonia
answers.a: Often from residual urine or sweat (especially when dehydrated), but UTIs or vaginal imbalances can also change odor. Stay hydrated, avoid douching or scented products, and see a clinician if it persists or comes with itching, burning, unusual discharge, or pelvic pain.
